pr_title: [ML] Allow a certain number of ill-formatted rows when delimited format is specified

timeline.message: [ML] Allow a certain number of ill-formatted rows when format is specified

timeline.body: I am willing to change this number. Though i do think we should have some static limit as it could break the automatic header row check if too many rows are poorly formatted.
timeline.bodyText: I am willing to change this number. Though i do think we should have some static limit as it could break the automatic header row check if too many rows are poorly formatted.
timeline.bodyHTML: I am willing to change this number. Though i do think we should have some static limit as it could break the automatic header row check if too many rows are poorly formatted.
timeline.author: benwtrent

replies.bodyText: That's ok for me. There has to be some default and maybe in the future that setting will become user-configurable...
replies.author: przemekwitek

timeline.body: I think we should have wiggle room here as well. Because the user supplying these fields implies they expect it to be delimited.
timeline.bodyText: I think we should have wiggle room here as well. Because the user supplying these fields implies they expect it to be delimited.
timeline.bodyHTML: I think we should have wiggle room here as well. Because the user supplying these fields implies they expect it to be delimited.
timeline.author: benwtrent

replies.bodyText:
If we do it here then we should also do it for the else branch below if format has been overridden to delimited.  (The easiest way to do this might be to change the condition above to else if (quote != null || shouldTrimFields != null || overrides.getFormat() == Format.DELIMITED).)
This does cause more problems though, for example, if a file has 12 semi-colons on all lines and 3 commas on 90% of lines we'll say it's CSV because we check that first.  It's probably OK, but we may want to tolerate fewer mismatches in this branch than the branch where the exact delimiter was specified.  (See my other comment about naming the constant.)
replies.author: droberts195

timeline.body:
So in your solution the size of the first row determines what is "normal", right?
If the first row has 5 fields and the rest of the rows have 6 fields each, the file will be rejected even though there is only one "odd" row?
I guess that's ok (it makes the code simpler) but wanted to make sure it is a conscious decision.
timeline.bodyText:

I guess that's ok (it makes the code simpler) but wanted to make sure it is a conscious decision.
timeline.author: przemekwitek

replies.bodyText:
Delimited parsing needs some sort of anchor to determine where things stand. The first row is usually a nice one as many files contain their header info.
I am not sure if we should anchor towards the first row or not, but that is how it was before my change :).
replies.author: benwtrent

replies.bodyText: I think it's OK for this iteration, but remember before this change every single row had to have the same number of fields, so the fact that the code achieved this by anchoring to the number of fields in the first row was an implementation detail.  After this change it becomes the externally visible policy.  But since it would complicate things a lot to change that and the new way of doing things is more tolerant than the old way, let's leave this as-is and see how many people cannot analyze a file because the first row has a different number of fields.

replies.bodyText:
The message should be adjusted to take account of short-circuiting in the loop above, for example:

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                    "Not {} because more than {} rows did not have the same number of fields as the first row({}). Bad rows {}",
          
          
            
                                    "Not {} because {} or more rows did not have the same number of fields as the first row ({}). Bad rows {}",
replies.author: droberts195

timeline.body:
I would rename it to sth resembling the `allowedFractionOfBadLines` parameter in the interface, e.g.: `DEFAULT_ALLOWED_FRACTION_OF_BAD_LINES`.
Also I'd consider employing the word "max": `maxAllowedFractionOfBadLines` but I do not feel very strongly about it.
timeline.bodyText:

replies.author: droberts195

timeline.body:
I think it should round up so that if the number of rows is small there's still a tolerance

```suggestion
                if (illFormattedRows.size() > Math.ceil(allowedFractionOfBadLines * numberOfRows) ) {
```

But also, this needs to short-circuit.  Imagine we have been told to analyse 50000 lines that are _not_ delimited.  With this change the code is now going to analyse all 50000 for all 4 default delimiters before ruling out the delimited formats.  And then it's going to provide 4 explanations each listing 49999 line numbers.  Therefore I think that:

1. This test needs to be inside the loop above, and `break` when the condition fails
2. The explanation message that lists bad rows needs to be rephrased to take this into account (see my other comment)

The explanation message that lists bad rows needs to be rephrased to take this into account (see my other comment)


`numberOfRows - 1` is based on how it was printed in the old explanation.
timeline.bodyHTML:

illFormattedRows.add(fieldsInFirstRow);

timeline.author: droberts195

timeline.body:
This highlights an interesting dilemma.  In this test it's obvious that the bad row is _really_ bad and should be ignored.  But what if the bad row was this?

```
2018-05-17T13:41:34\n
```

Then a human interpreting the file would probably say that the row just had an empty message, and should be processed as such.

I think it would be interesting to look at the specific examples of where people have complained that we couldn't import their CSV files and see if the "bad" rows in the real-world examples fall into the category of unusably bad or just missing the last field.  Missing any field other than the last would fall into the category of unusably bad because it would mess up field mapping type analysis.

The decision of whether or not we ignore the bad rows should be documented in https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/ml-find-file-structure.html.  Probably the best place to do this is in the description of the `delimiter` override, where we can tell people that by explicitly specifying the delimiter we're slightly tolerant of bad lines and what happens to the bad lines.

replies.bodyText:
Examples we have are:

elastic/kibana#31065 - summary rows => inappropriate to include
elastic/kibana#60196 (comment) - missing last column => would be good to include

So one of each 🤦
So for this PR it's probably best that the bad rows get ignored from the analysis.  But we need to document that, as people will be losing data.  Also, what does the end-to-end experience look like, including file import?  Does the CSV ingest processor report errors for the bad rows that get propagated back to the file data visualizer?  I guess even in the long run if it's impossible to configure the CSV ingest processor to treat missing trailing columns as empty then we'll always have to ignore rows with fewer fields than the header row.
replies.author: droberts195

replies.bodyText:
I will verify the following, but my gut is that these should be the actions on our two scenarios:


missing a value in the middle: this could probably end up causing an ingest failure. I am pretty sure the UI shows what the bulk ingest failures were, and these usually say "field foo could not be mapped to type bar".


missing value at the end: Doc should import fully without issues as there will be no mapping conflicts. The field is just null or missing from the resulting doc. Zero data loss.
replies.author: benwtrent
benwtrent

replies.bodyText:
OK that's interesting.  So you get past the CSV processor if you have fewer columns in a row than you have header columns.  After that the document may or may not get ingested depending on whether fields clash with subsequent processors.  So badrow cannot be parsed as a date, but if the first column had been a keyword field rather than a date then that would have gone through.
I think this actually isn't too bad.  If we deduce mappings based on the rows containing all the header fields, and then others get ingested or not depending on how unexpectedly different they were.
replies.author: droberts195

timeline.body:
To prove the last line (and maybe the bad line depending on the decision from my other comment) get included, it would be good to assert on the value of `structure.getNumMessagesAnalyzed()` here.  It should be 10 if the bad line gets excluded and 11 if it gets included.

I actually don't understand how we're getting past the check at https://github.com/super-csv/super-csv/blob/208d3082cd5cdab39da8873cf741f8b672d1af5b/super-csv/src/main/java/org/supercsv/util/Util.java#L122-L128 which we call from https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/9521e4f0590c7550f278b88d51dc6e3e159ff403/x-pack/plugin/ml/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/xpack/ml/filestructurefinder/DelimitedFileStructureFinder.java#L84-L85 when we hit the bad row.  SuperCSV throws an exception here, which I would have thought would terminate the analysis, so this may be a sign of some other bug that's existed for a long time or it may be working for some reason I don't understand.

replies.author: benwtrent

timeline.body:
I think there's a problem here that I didn't think of when I suggested to move the check inside the loop.

If the bad row comes very early on then this will trigger when the overall proportion of bad lines in the file is within the tolerance.

You should be able to reproduce this by making your bad row the second non-header row in your test case.  At the point it occurs 50% of rows will be bad.

So, we need a formula that will short-circuit as soon as it's impossible for the overall percentage to be within the tolerance (which will be on the first bad row in the no overrides case) but not sooner.  Unfortunately we don't know the number of CSV rows for sure because some could be multi-line.  Assuming worst case, let's make the formula work on the basis that every subsequent sample line is one row, and they're all good.  That leads to:

```suggestion
                        if (illFormattedRows.size() > Math.ceil(allowedFractionOfBadLines * (numberOfRows + numberOfLinesInSample - csvReader.getLineNumber()))) {
```

There might be an off-by-one error in that formula depending on exactly what `csvReader.getLineNumber()` after reading a row.

The next problem is that `numberOfLinesInSample` isn't known in this method.  `FileStructureFinderManager.sampleFile()` knows it, so you could change that to return it and pass it through to the `canCreate___` methods, or maybe there is somewhere else it's more convenient to get it from.

Unfortunately we don't know the number of CSV rows for sure because some could be multi-line.
